date: stated on September 1, 2019 in a tweet:
title: The evidence shows that most of the 47 men on the famous Independence Declaration board were slaves.
text: As the nation celebrates the 400th anniversary of slavery, a documentary filmmaker in Chicago tweeted about the Declaration of Independence, which was hanging in the American Capitol Building. The painting depicts a moment in 1776 showing 47 men, including Thomas Jefferson, John Hancock and Ben Franklin, most of whom were signatories to the Declaration. "This is one of the most famous paintings in American history: Declaration of Independence," Arlene Parsa wrote above the 1818 oil picture by John Trumbol. "I have decided to put red points on all men who hold slaves. The next time someone puts them on a base and says we can't question their judgment on guns or whatever, show them this picture." So, Parsa claims that 34 of the 47 founding fathers who appeared in the painting were slaves. While warning that there is no single final source of this issue, we have also calculated 34. We've contacted more than a dozen historians and historical organizations. No one knew about a list of the number of men in the painting who were slave owners. "I was going to assume it would be easy to figure out how many slaves owned, but it's surprisingly far-fetched," said the history professor at Baylor Thomas Cade University. Starting with the evidence Parsa submitted to support his claim, we did our own research on each of the 47. (This chart identifies all 47.) "Most quantitative measurement is the best guess based on available records," said historian Terry Boton at the University of Maryland, Baltimore County. "The problem is that property records are a beautiful spot for the most mysterious founders and even some bigger names." But using books, historical organizations, research articles and other sources, we found that there is strong evidence to support Parsa's claim. The owners of slavery tend to be men of means, including landowners, doctors, lawyers and local government officials.
